docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Behind Those Medical Malpractice Rates'' (Business Day, Feb. 22), you report that ''while claims are rising at a measured pace, there have been more headline-grabbing big awards.'' This is frustrating to physicians and patients living in states without medical liability reforms, where these big awards lead to skyrocketing medical liability insurance premiums, putting patient access to care at risk. Reforms that include a cap on pain and suffering stabilize premiums, which is why 73 percent of Americans support them.
docs.abstract: American Medical Assn Pres Dr John C Nelson letter says states with caps on pain and suffering awards have stabilized medical liability insurance premiums, whereas doctors in states without caps pay much more in malpractice insurance (Feb 22 article)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     In ''Behind Those Medical Malpractice Rates'' (Business Day, Feb. 22), you report that ''while claims are rising at a measured pace, there have been more headline-grabbing big awards.'' This is frustrating to physicians and...

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush told governors on Monday that he wanted to work with them to rein in the soaring cost of Medicaid, the health insurance program for more than 50 million low-income people. But governors said they were far from reaching an agreement with the White House. ''We want Medicaid to work,'' Mr. Bush told the governors, who were visiting the White House as part of their winter conference. ''We also recognize that the system needs to be reformed, and we want to work with you to do so.''

headline.main: Governors Resist Bush's Appeal for Quick Deal on Medicaid

docs.abstract: Pres Bush, in appeal for quick agreement, tells group of governors visiting White House that he wants to work with them to curtail cost of Medicaid, but governors say they are not ready to reach agreement; Pres Bush has proposed cutting $60 billion from federal Medicaid spending over 10 years; governors want more discretion in deciding who receives benefits, but fear costs will be shifted to states without easing of federal requirements (M)
docs.snippet: President Bush told governors that he wanted to work with them to rein in the soaring cost of Medicaid.
